frames.core

Class Frame

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.core.Frame
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Shape

    public class Frame
extends java.lang.Object
    A frame is a 2D or 3D coordinate system, represented by a position(), an orientation() and magnitude(). The order of these transformations is important: the frame is first translated, then rotated around the new translated origin and then scaled. This class API partially conforms that of the great libQGLViewer Frame.

    Hierarchy of frames

    The frame position, orientation and magnitude are actually defined with respect to a reference() frame. The default reference() is the world coordinate system (represented by a null reference()). If you setReference(Frame) to a different frame, you must then differentiate:
    • The local translation(), rotation() and scaling(), defined with respect to the reference() which represents an angle preserving transformation of space.
    • The global position(), orientation() and magnitude(), always defined with respect to the world coordinate system.

    A frame is actually defined by its translation() with respect to its reference(), then by rotation() of the coordinate system around the new translated origin and then by a uniform positive scaling() along its rotated axes.

    This terminology for local (translation(), rotation() and scaling()) and global (position(), orientation() and magnitude()) definitions is used in all the methods' names and should be enough to prevent ambiguities. These notions are obviously identical when the reference() is null, i.e., when the frame is defined in the world coordinate system (the one you are left with after calling a graph preDraw() method).

    Geometry transformations

    A frame is useful to define the position, orientation and magnitude of an arbitrary object which may represent a point-of-view.

    Use matrix() to access the frame coordinate system, as when drawing an object locally:

    // Builds a frame at position (0.5,0,0) and oriented such that its Y axis is along the (1,1,1) direction
    Frame frame = new Frame(new Vector(0.5,0,0), new Quaternion(new Vector(0,1,0), new Vector(1,1,1)));
    graph.pushModelView();
    graph.applyModelView(frame.matrix());
    // Draw your object here, in the local frame coordinate system.
    graph.popModelView();

    Use view() when rendering the scene from the frame point-of-view. Note this this method is used by the graph when a frame is set as its eye.

    To transform a point from one frame to another use location(Vector, Frame) and worldLocation(Vector). To instead transform a vector (such as a normal) use displacement(Vector, Frame) and worldDisplacement(Vector).

    Hierarchical traversals

    Hierarchical traversals of the frame hierarchy which automatically apply the local frame transformations described above may be achieved with Graph.traverse(). Automatic traversals require overriding visit() and to instantiate a frame attached to a graph which is referred to as attached frame (see isAttached(Graph) and isDetached()).

    To instantiate an attached frame use the frame constructors that take a graph parameter or a (reference) frame which in turn is attached to a graph. Once instantiated, a frame cannot be attached nor detached, but a copy of it can (see attach(Graph) and detach()).

    Constraints

    One interesting feature of a frame is that its displacements can be constrained. When a Constraint is attached to a frame, it filters the input of translate(Vector) and rotate(Quaternion), and only the resulting filtered motion is applied to the frame. The default constraint() is null resulting in no filtering. Use setConstraint(Constraint) to attach a constraint to a frame.

    Classical constraints are provided for convenience (see LocalConstraint, WorldConstraint and EyeConstraint) and new constraints can very easily be implemented.

    Syncing

    Two frames can be synced together (sync(Frame, Frame)), meaning that they will share their global parameters (position, orientation and magnitude) taken the one that has been most recently updated. Syncing can be useful to share frames among different off-screen canvases.

    Picking

    Picking a frame is done accordingly to a precision(). Refer to setPrecision(Precision) for details.

    Application Control

    Implementing an application control for the frame is a two step process:
    • Parse user gesture data by overriding interact(Object...).
    • Send gesture data to the frame by calling Graph.defaultHIDControl(Object...), Graph.control(String, Object...) or Graph.control(Frame, Object...).

      • isAttached

        public boolean isAttached(Graph graph)
        Tells whether or not this frame belongs to the hierarchy (see Graph.traverse()). To test if the frame is detach from any graph hierarchy call isAttached(null).

        Note that a call to children() never returns null if the frame is attached to a graph, i.e., that graph will visit the frame during traversal.

        See Also:
        isDetached(), Graph.traverse()

      • isDetached

        public boolean isDetached()
        Same as return isAttached(null).

        Note that a call to children() always returns null if the frame is detached, i.e., the frame is not available for graph traversal (see Graph.traverse()).

        See Also:
        isAttached(Graph), Graph.traverse()

      • set

        public void set(Frame frame)
        Sets position(), orientation() and magnitude() values from those of the frame. The frame graph(), reference() and constraint() are not affected by this call.

        After calling set(frame) a call to this.matches(frame) should return true.

        See Also:
        reset(), worldMatrix()

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Sets an identity frame by resetting its translation(), rotation() and scaling(). The frame graph(), reference() and constraint() are not affected by this call. Call set(null) if you want to reset the global position(), orientation() and magnitude() frame parameters instead.
        See Also:
        set(Frame)

      • id

        public int id()
        Uniquely identifies the frame. Also the color to be used for picking with a color buffer. See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2262100/rgb-int-to-rgb-python

      • sync

        public static void sync(Frame frame1,
                        Frame frame2)
        If frame1 has been more recently updated than frame2, calls frame2.set(frame1), otherwise calls frame1.set(frame2). Does nothing if both objects were updated at the same time.

        This method syncs only the global geometry attributes (position(), orientation() and magnitude()) among the two frames. The reference() and constraint() (if any) of each frame are kept separately.

        See Also:
        set(Frame)

        Returns true if frame is reference() this frame.

        public static java.util.List<Frame> path(Frame tail,
                                         Frame tip)
        Returns an array containing a straight path of frames from tail to tip. Returns an empty list if tail is not ancestor of tip.
        See Also:
        isAncestor(Frame, Frame)

      • reference

        public Frame reference()
        Returns the reference frame, in which this frame is defined.

        The frame translation(), rotation() and scaling() are defined with respect to the reference() coordinate system. A null reference frame (default value) means that the frame is defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use position(), orientation() and magnitude() to recursively convert values along the reference frame chain and to get values expressed in the world coordinate system. The values match when the reference frame is null.

        Use setReference(Frame) to set this value and create a frame hierarchy. Convenient functions allow you to convert coordinates and vectors from one frame to another: see location(Vector, Frame) and displacement(Vector, Frame), respectively.

      • resetReference

        public void resetReference()
        Same as setReference(null).
        See Also:
        setReference(Frame)

      • setReference

        public void setReference(Frame frame)
        Sets the reference() of the frame.

        The frame translation(), rotation() and scaling() are then defined in the reference() coordinate system.

        Use position(), orientation() and magnitude() to express the frame global transformation in the world coordinate system.

        Using this method, you can create a hierarchy of frames. This hierarchy needs to be a tree, which root is the world coordinate system (i.e., null reference()). No action is performed if setting reference as the reference() would create a loop in the hierarchy.

      • children

        public java.util.List<Frame> children()
        Returns the list a child frames of this frame. Only meaningful if this frame isAttached(Graph) to a graph. Returns null if this frame isDetached().

      • randomize

        public void randomize()
        Same as randomize(graph().center(), graph().radius(), graph().is3D()).

        Does nothing if the frame isDetached().

        See Also:
        randomize(Vector, float, boolean), Vector.randomize(), Quaternion.randomize(), random(Graph), random(Vector, float, boolean)

      • randomize

        public void randomize(Vector center,
                      float radius,
                      boolean is3D)
        Randomized this frame. The frame is randomly re-positioned inside the ball defined by center and radius, which in 2D is a circumference parallel to the x-y plane. The orientation() is randomized by Quaternion.randomize(). The new magnitude is a random in old-magnitude * [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        randomize(), Vector.randomize(), Quaternion.randomize(), random(Graph), random(Vector, float, boolean)

      • random

        public static Frame random(Graph graph)
        Returns a random frame attached to graph. The frame is randomly positioned inside the graph viewing volume which is defined by Graph.center() and Graph.radius() (see Vector.random()). The orientation() is set by Quaternion.random(). The magnitude is a random in [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        random(Vector, float, boolean), Vector.random(), Quaternion.random(), randomize(), randomize(Vector, float, boolean)

      • random

        public static Frame random(Vector center,
                           float radius,
                           boolean is3D)
        Returns a random detached frame. The frame is randomly positioned inside the ball defined by center and radius (see Vector.random()), which in 2D is a circumference parallel to the x-y plane. The orientation() is set by Quaternion.random(). The magnitude is a random in [0,5...2].
        See Also:
        random(Graph), Vector.random(), Quaternion.random(), randomize(), randomize(Vector, float, boolean)

      • precision

        public Frame.Precision precision()
        Returns the frame picking precision. See setPrecision(Precision) for details.
        See Also:
        setPrecision(Precision), setPrecisionThreshold(float), precisionThreshold()

      • setPrecision

        public void setPrecision(Frame.Precision precision)
        Sets the frame picking precision.

        When precision() is Frame.Precision.FIXED or Frame.Precision.ADAPTIVE Picking is done by checking if the pointer lies within a squared area around the frame position() screen projection which size is defined by setPrecisionThreshold(float).

        When precision() is Frame.Precision.EXACT, picking is done in a precise manner according to the projected pixels of the visual representation related to the frame. It is meant to be implemented by derived classes (providing the means attach a visual representation to the frame) and requires the graph to implement a back buffer.

        Default implementation of this policy will behave like Frame.Precision.FIXED.

        See Also:
        precision(), setPrecisionThreshold(float), precisionThreshold()

      • setPrecisionThreshold

        public void setPrecisionThreshold(float threshold)
        Sets the length of the squared area around the frame position() screen projection that defined the frame picking condition.

        If precision() is Frame.Precision.FIXED, the threshold is expressed in pixels and directly defines the fixed length of a 'shooter target', centered at the projection of the frame origin onto the screen.

        If precision() is Frame.Precision.ADAPTIVE, the threshold is expressed in object space (world units) and defines the edge length of a squared bounding box that leads to an adaptive length of a 'shooter target', centered at the projection of the frame origin onto the screen. Use this version only if you have a good idea of the bounding box size of the object you are attaching to the frame shape.

        The value is meaningless when the precision() is* Frame.Precision.EXACT. See setPrecision(Precision) for details.

        Default behavior is to set the PRECISIONTHRESHOLD (in a non-adaptive manner) to 20.

        Negative threshold values are silently ignored.

        See Also:
        precision(), setPrecision(Precision), precisionThreshold()

      • precisionThreshold

        public float precisionThreshold()
        Returns the picking precision threshold in pixels used by Graph.tracks(float, float, Frame).
        See Also:
        setPrecisionThreshold(float), precision(), setPrecision(Precision)

      • constraint

        public Constraint constraint()
        Returns the current Constraint applied to the frame.

        A null value (default) means that no constraint is used to filter the frame translation and rotation.

        See the Constraint class documentation for details.

      • setConstraint

        public void setConstraint(Constraint constraint)
        Sets the constraint() attached to the frame.

        A null value means set no constraint (also reset it if there was one).

      • translation

        public Vector translation()
        Returns the frame translation, defined with respect to the reference().

        Use position() to get the result in world coordinates. These two values are identical when the reference() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setTranslation(Vector)

      • setTranslation

        public void setTranslation(Vector translation)
        Sets the translation() of the frame, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        Use setPosition(Vector) to define the world coordinates position().

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint)

      • setTranslation

        public void setTranslation(float x,
                           float y)
        Same as setTranslation(Vector), but with float parameters.

      • setTranslation

        public void setTranslation(float x,
                           float y,
                           float z)
        Same as setTranslation(Vector), but with float parameters.

      • translate

        public void translate(float x,
                      float y,
                      float z)
        Same as translate(Vector) but with float parameters.

      • translate

        public void translate(float x,
                      float y)
        Same as translate(Vector) but with float parameters.

      • translate

        public void translate(Vector vector)
        Translates the frame according to vector, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        If there's a constraint() it is satisfied. Hence the translation actually applied to the frame may differ from vector (since it can be filtered by the constraint()).

        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion), scale(float)

      • position

        public Vector position()
        Returns the frame position defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        orientation(), magnitude(), setPosition(Vector), translation()

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(Vector position)
        Sets the frame position(), defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use setTranslation(Vector) to define the local frame translation (with respect to the reference()).

        Note that the potential constraint() of the frame is taken into account, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint)

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(float x,
                        float y)
        Same as setPosition(Vector), but with float parameters.

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(float x,
                        float y,
                        float z)
        Same as setPosition(Vector), but with float parameters.

      • rotation

        public Quaternion rotation()
        Returns the frame rotation, defined with respect to the reference() (i.e, the current Quaternion orientation).

        Use orientation() to get the result in world coordinates. These two values are identical when the reference() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setRotation(Quaternion)

      • setRotation

        public void setRotation(float x,
                        float y,
                        float z,
                        float w)
        Same as setRotation(Quaternion) but with float Quaternion parameters.

      • setRotation

        public void setRotation(Quaternion rotation)
        Set the current rotation. See the different Quaternion constructors.

        Sets the frame rotation(), locally defined with respect to the reference(). Use setOrientation(Quaternion) to define the world coordinates orientation().

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint), rotation(), setTranslation(Vector)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(Quaternion quaternion)
        Rotates the frame by quaternion (defined in the frame coordinate system): rotation().compose(quaternion).

        Note that if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

        See Also:
        setConstraint(Constraint), translate(Vector)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(Vector axis,
                   float angle)
        Same as rotate(new Quaternion(axis, angle)).
        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(float x,
                   float y,
                   float z,
                   float angle)
        Same as rotate(new Vector(x,y,z), angle).
        See Also:
        rotate(Vector, float)

      • orbit

        public void orbit(Vector axis,
                  float angle)
        Same as { orbit(new Quaternion(axis, angle))}.
        See Also:
        orbit(Quaternion)

      • orbit

        public void orbit(Vector axis,
                  float angle,
                  Frame frame)
        Same as orbit(new Quaternion(axis, angle), frame).
        See Also:
        orbit(Quaternion, Frame)

      • orbit

        public void orbit(Quaternion quaternion)
        Same as orbit(quaternion, null).
        See Also:
        orbit(Quaternion, Frame)

      • orbit

        public void orbit(Quaternion quaternion,
                  Frame frame)
        Rotates this frame around frame (which may be null for the world coordinate system) according to quaternion.

        The quaternion axes (see Quaternion.axis()) is defined in the frame coordinate system.

        Note: if there's a constraint() it is satisfied, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

      • orientation

        public Quaternion orientation()
        Returns the orientation of the frame, defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        position(), magnitude(), setOrientation(Quaternion), rotation()

      • setOrientation

        public void setOrientation(Quaternion quaternion)
        Sets the orientation() of the frame, defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use setRotation(Quaternion) to define the local frame rotation (with respect to the reference()).

        Note that the potential constraint() of the frame is taken into account, i.e., to bypass a frame constraint simply reset it (see setConstraint(Constraint)).

      • setOrientation

        public void setOrientation(float x,
                           float y,
                           float z,
                           float w)
        Same as setOrientation(Quaternion), but with float parameters.

      • scaling

        public float scaling()
        Returns the frame scaling, defined with respect to the reference().

        Use magnitude() to get the result in world coordinates. These two values are identical when the reference() is null (default).

        See Also:
        setScaling(float)

      • setScaling

        public void setScaling(float scaling)
        Sets the scaling() of the frame, locally defined with respect to the reference().

        Use setMagnitude(float) to define the world coordinates magnitude().

      • scale

        public void scale(float scaling)
        Scales the frame according to scaling, locally defined with respect to the reference().
        See Also:
        rotate(Quaternion), translate(Vector)

      • magnitude

        public float magnitude()
        Returns the magnitude of the frame, defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        orientation(), position(), setPosition(Vector), translation()

      • setMagnitude

        public void setMagnitude(float magnitude)
        Sets the magnitude() of the frame, defined in the world coordinate system.

        Use setScaling(float) to define the local frame scaling (with respect to the reference()).

      • align

        public void align()
        Same as align(null).
        See Also:

      • align

        public void align(Frame frame)
        Convenience function that simply calls align(false, 0.85f, frame)
        See Also:

      • align

        public void align(boolean move)
        Same as align(move, null).
        See Also:

      • align

                  Frame frame)
        Convenience function that simply calls align(move, 0.85f, frame).
        See Also:
        align(boolean, float, Frame)

      • align

        public void align(float threshold)
        Same as align(threshold, null).
        See Also:
        align(boolean, Frame)

      • align

        public void align(float threshold,
                  Frame frame)
        Convenience function that simply calls align(false, threshold, frame).
        See Also:
        align(boolean, float, Frame)

      • align

        public void align(boolean move,
                  float threshold)
        Same as align(move, threshold, null).
        See Also:
        align(boolean, float, Frame)

      • align

        public void align(boolean move,
                  float threshold,
                  Frame frame)
        Aligns the frame with frame, so that two of their axis are parallel.

        If one of the X, Y and Z axis of the Frame is almost parallel to any of the X, Y, or Z axis of frame, the Frame is rotated so that these two axis actually become parallel.

        If, after this first rotation, two other axis are also almost parallel, a second alignment is performed. The two frames then have identical orientations, up to 90 degrees rotations.

        threshold measures how close two axis must be to be considered parallel. It is compared with the absolute values of the dot product of the normalized axis.

        When move is set to true, the Frame position() is also affected by the alignment. The new Frame position() is such that the frame frame position (computed with location(Vector), in the Frame coordinates system) does not change.

        frame may be null and then represents the world coordinate system (same convention than for the reference()).

      • projectOnLine

        public void projectOnLine(Vector origin,
                          Vector direction)
        Translates the frame so that its position() lies on the line defined by origin and direction (defined in the world coordinate system).

        Simply uses an orthogonal projection. direction does not need to be normalized.

      • setXAxis

        public void setXAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its xAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        xAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

      • setYAxis

        public void setYAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its yAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        yAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

      • setZAxis

        public void setZAxis(Vector axis)
        Rotates the frame so that its zAxis() becomes axis defined in the world coordinate system. Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. See Quaternion.fromTo(Vector, Vector).
        See Also:
        zAxis(), setYAxis(Vector), setZAxis(Vector)

        public Vector xAxis()
        Same as return xAxis(true)
        See Also:

      • xAxis

        public Vector xAxis(boolean positive)
        Returns the x-axis of the frame, represented as a normalized vector defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setXAxis(Vector), yAxis(), zAxis()

        Same as return yAxis(true)

        Same as return zAxis(true)

      • zAxis

        public Vector zAxis(boolean positive)
        Returns the z-axis of the frame, represented as a normalized vector defined in the world coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setZAxis(Vector), xAxis(), yAxis()

      • matrix

        public Matrix matrix()
        Returns the local transformation matrix represented by the frame.

        This method could be used in conjunction with pushMatrix(), popMatrix() and applyMatrix() to modify a graph modelView() matrix from a frame hierarchy. For example, with this frame hierarchy:

        Frame body = new Frame();
        Frame leftArm = new Frame();
        Frame rightArm = new Frame();
        leftArm.setReference(body);
        rightArm.setReference(body);

        The associated drawing code should look like:

        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(body.matrix());
        drawBody();
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(leftArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        graph.popModelView();
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyMatrix(rightArm.matrix());
        drawArm();
        graph.popModelView();
        graph.popModelView();

        Note the use of nested pushModelView() and popModelView() blocks to represent the frame hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

        This matrix only represents the local frame transformation (i.e., with respect to the reference()). Use worldMatrix() to get the full Frame transformation matrix (i.e., from the world to the Frame coordinate system). These two match when the reference() is null. Attention: In Processing this technique is inefficient because papplet.applyMatrix will try to calculate the inverse of the transform. Use Graph.applyTransformation(Frame) instead.

        See Also:
        set(Frame), worldMatrix(), view()

      • worldMatrix

        public Matrix worldMatrix()
        Returns the global transformation matrix represented by the frame which grants direct access to it, without the need to traverse its ancestor hierarchy first (as it is the case with matrix()).

        This method should be used in conjunction with applyMatrix() to modify a graph modelView() matrix from a frame:

        // Here the modelview matrix corresponds to the world coordinate system.
        Frame frame = new Frame(translation, new Rotation(from, to));
        graph.applyModelView(frame.worldMatrix());
        // draw object in the frame coordinate system.

        This matrix represents the global frame transformation: the entire reference() hierarchy is taken into account to define the frame transformation from the world coordinate system. Use matrix() to get the local frame transformation matrix (i.e. defined with respect to the reference()). These two match when the reference() is null.

        See Also:
        set(Frame), matrix(), view()

      • view

        public Matrix view()
        Returns the inverse of the matrix associated with the frame position and orientation that is to be used when the frame represents an eye. This matrix matches the inverted of the worldMatrix() when scaling() is 1.

        The view matrix converts from the world coordinates system to the eye coordinates system, so that coordinates can then be projected on screen using a projection matrix.

        See Also:
        Matrix.view(Vector, Quaternion), matrix(), worldMatrix(), set(Frame), set(Frame)

      • fromMatrix

        public void fromMatrix(Matrix matrix)
        Sets the frame from a matrix() representation: rotation and scaling in the upper left 3x3 matrix and translation on the last column.

        Hence, if your openGL code fragment looks like:

        float [] m = new float [16]; m[0]=...;
        gl.glMultMatrixf(m);

        It is equivalent to write:

        Frame frame = new Frame();
        frame.fromMatrix(m);
        graph.pushModelView();
        graph.applyModelView(frame.matrix());
        // You are in the local frame coordinate system.
        graph.popModelView();

        Which allows to apply local transformations to the frame while using geometry data from other frame instances when necessary (see location(Vector, Frame) and displacement(Vector, Frame)).

        See Also:
        fromWorldMatrix(Matrix), matrix()

      • fromWorldMatrix

        public void fromWorldMatrix(Matrix matrix)
        Sets the frame from worldMatrix() representation: orientation and magnitude in the upper left 3x3 matrix and position on the last column.

        Hence, if your openGL code fragment looks like:

        float [] m = new float [16]; m[0]=...;
        gl.glMultMatrixf(m);

        It is equivalent to write:

        Frame frame = new Frame();
        frame.fromWorldMatrix(m);
        graph.applyModelView(frame.matrix());
        // You are in the local frame coordinate system.

        Which allows to apply local transformations to the frame while using geometry data from other frame instances when necessary (see location(Vector, Frame) and displacement(Vector, Frame)).

        See Also:
        fromMatrix(Matrix), worldMatrix()

      • inverse

        public Frame inverse()
        Returns a frame representing the inverse of this frame space transformation.

        The new frame rotation() is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original rotation. Its translation() is the negated inverse rotated image of the original translation. Its scaling() is 1 / original scaling.

        If a frame is considered as a space rigid transformation, i.e., translation and rotation, but no scaling (scaling=1), the inverse() frame performs the inverse transformation.

        Only the local frame transformation (i.e., defined with respect to the reference()) is inverted. Use worldInverse() for a global inverse.

        The resulting frame has the same reference() as the this frame and a null constraint().

        See Also:
        worldInverse()

      • worldInverse

        public Frame worldInverse()
        Returns the inverse() of the frame world transformation.

        The orientation() of the new frame is the Quaternion.inverse() of the original orientation. Its position() is the negated and inverse rotated image of the original position. The magnitude() is the original magnitude multiplicative inverse.

        The result frame has a null reference() and a null constraint().

        Use inverse() for a local (i.e., with respect to reference()) transformation inverse.

        See Also:
        inverse()

      • displacement

        public Vector displacement(Vector vector)
        Converts vector displacement from world to this frame. Same as return displacement(vector, null). location(Vector) converts locations instead of displacements.
        See Also:
        displacement(Vector, Frame), location(Vector)

      • displacement

        public Vector displacement(Vector vector,
                           Frame frame)
        Converts vector displacement from frame to this frame. Use frame.displacement(vector, this) to perform the inverse transformation. location(Vector, Frame) converts locations instead of displacements.
        See Also:
        displacement(Vector), worldDisplacement(Vector)

      • worldDisplacement

        public Vector worldDisplacement(Vector vector)
        Converts vector displacement from this frame to world. displacement(Vector) performs the inverse transformation. worldLocation(Vector) converts locations instead of displacements.
        See Also:
        location(Vector), displacement(Vector, Frame)

      • location

        public Vector location(Vector vector)
        Converts vector location from world to this frame. Same as return location(vector, null). displacement(Vector) converts displacements instead of locations.
        See Also:
        location(Vector, Frame), displacement(Vector)

      • location

        public Vector location(Vector vector,
                       Frame frame)
        Converts vector location from frame to this frame. Use frame.location(vector, this) to perform the inverse transformation. displacement(Vector, Frame) converts displacements instead of locations.
        See Also:
        location(Vector), worldLocation(Vector)

      • worldLocation

        public Vector worldLocation(Vector vector)
        Converts vector location from this frame to world. location(Vector) performs the inverse transformation. worldDisplacement(Vector) converts displacements instead of locations.
        See Also:
        displacement(Vector), location(Vector, Frame)

      • graph

        public Graph graph()
        Returns the graph this frame is attached to. Always returns false if the frame isDetached().

      • isTrackingEnabled

        public boolean isTrackingEnabled()
        Returns true if tracking is enabled.
        See Also:
        enableTracking(boolean)

      • enableTracking

        public void enableTracking(boolean flag)
        Enables frame tracking according to flag. When tracking is disabled Graph.tracks(Point, Frame) returns false, Graph.setTrackedFrame(String, Frame) does nothing while Graph.track(String, Point) and Graph.cast(String, Point) would bypass the frame.
        See Also:
        isTrackingEnabled()

      • isTracked

        public boolean isTracked()
        Same as return isDetached() ? false : isTracked(graph()). Use it if the frame is attached to a graph(). Use isTracked(Graph) if the frame isDetached().
        See Also:
        isDetached(), isTracked(Graph)

      • isTracked

        public boolean isTracked(Graph graph)
        Returns true if the frame is being tracked by at least one graph hid and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        Graph.isTrackedFrame(String, Frame), Graph.isTrackedFrame(Frame)

      • interact

        public void interact(java.lang.Object... gesture)
        Parse gesture params. Useful to implement the frame as an for application control. Default implementation is empty. , i.e., it is meant to be implemented by derived classes.

      • visit

        public void visit()
        Procedure called on the frame by the graph traversal algorithm. Default implementation is empty, i.e., it is meant to be implemented by derived classes. Only meaningful if the frame is attached to a graph.

        Hierarchical culling, i.e., culling of the frame and its children, should be decided here. Set the culling flag with cull(boolean) according to your culling condition: 

         
 frame = new Frame(graph) {
   public void visit() {
     // Hierarchical culling is optional and disabled by default. When the cullingCondition
     // (which should be implemented by you) is true, scene.traverse() will prune the branch
     // at the frame
     cull(cullingCondition);
     if(!isCulled())
       // Draw your object here, in the local coordinate system.
   }
 }
        See Also:
        Graph.traverse(), cull(boolean), isCulled()

      • cull

        public void cull()
        Same as cull(true). Only meaningful if the frame is attached to a graph.
        See Also:
        cull(boolean), isCulled()

      • cull

        public void cull(boolean cull)
        Enables or disables visit() of this frame and its children during Graph.traverse(). Culling should be decided within visit(). Only meaningful if the frame is attached to a graph.
        See Also:
        isCulled()

      • isCulled

        public boolean isCulled()
        Returns whether or not the frame culled or not. Culled frames (and their children) will not be visited by the Graph.traverse() algorithm. Always returns false if the frame isDetached().
        See Also:
        cull(boolean)
